thread.title: Woman held in kidnapping of 4-year-old Scottsdale boy
thread.title_full: Woman held in kidnapping of 4-year-old Scottsdale boy

author: Diego Mendoza-Moyers , The Republic | azcentral.com
title: Woman held in kidnapping of 4-year-old Scottsdale boy
text:
CLOSE Skip in Skip x Embed
x Share
Tiffany Noelle Baginski, 30, was arrested in Scottsdale on Feb. 9, 2017 on suspicion of kidnapping a 4-year-old boy from his home. Maricopa County Superior Court 
Tiffany Baginski (Photo: Maricopa County Sheriff's Office) 
317 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN COMMENT EMAIL MORE A Scottsdale woman has been arrested on suspicion of kidnapping a 4-year-old boy from an apartment after luring him outside to play, police and court records said.
According to statements from police included in court documents, 30-year-old Tiffany Baginski coaxed the boy out of an apartment in the 6600 block of Avalon Drive in Scottsdale just before 3 p.m. Thursday.
The boy's grandmother, who told police she had the front door open but the screen door closed, came out of her bedroom to find the boy was gone, according to records.
After Scottsdale police searched the area, they arrested Baginksi after finding her walking with the boy north of the apartment just before 3:30 p.m., said police spokesman Sgt. Ben Hoster.
Baginski told police she had seen the boy in a park near the apartment before and wanted to take him to get ice cream, according to a police narrative included in court records. The mother and grandmother of the victim told police they did not know Baginski and had never talked to her before, according to records.
After getting him out of the apartment, Baginski told police she took the victim to her boyfriend's apartment nearby, then went to buy ice cream before going back to the boyfriend's residence, records said.
During a forensic examination, a nurse noted that the boy had sustained injuries, and the victim said "something happened" to his clothing, and he had been touched or tickled in his groin area, the court document said.
After receiving a warrant to search the apartment where Baginski lived with her boyfriend, push-pop ice cream wrappers were found on the floor, records said. The boyfriend told police he was not involved in abducting the boy, and both he and Baginski denied that anything sexual happened, according to court documents.
Baginski is being held without bail in a Maricopa County jail for investigation of one count each of kidnapping and custodial interference. Baginski has a prior felony conviction, court records said.
Police told The Republic that the woman's boyfriend was not under arrest as of Friday afternoon.
